At least we know that Ahlmann had Sverdrup in mind in late December 1928. At that time Ahlmann wrote to his colleague, Norwegian geo-scientist Adolf Hoel, that he has 'turned to H.U. Sverdrup and Lauge Koch [the Danish geologist of Greenland] to ask for their assistance in preparing the sections on the Polar Sea and Greenland' for an article that he was invited to write for Nordisk Tidskrift, see Ahlmann letter to Adolf Hoel 27 December 1928, Hoel papers, Norwegian Polar Institute Collection, nr 89 A5/2/5, Tromsö national archives, University of Tromsö; (1930), It was a problem for Sverdrup to pick up the medal on the 'Vega day' 24 April because of a research stint in the United States in the spring of Sverdrup to Ahlmann 21 February and 17 March 1930. It is almost certain that Ahlmann and Sverdrup met before 1930, likely in Bergen, where Ahlmann often paid visits to the home of his wife's parents. In his letter to Ahlmann 21 February 1930, thanking for the telegram that informed him of the Vega medal, Sverdrup referred to having observed Ahlmann's 'pondering on something [the medal?] at Christmas', which indicates that they had met at least then, and references to geophysical colleagues like Håkon Mosby and Bjørn Helland-Hansen in their Correspondence supports the view that Bergen was a place where they both had moved simultaneously for several years and should have made some acquaintance; (1930), Sverdrup to Ahlmann 18 September, 7 October (accepting to write), 15 October (sending his 3800 word manuscript), 1 November (accepting cuts).
